title: Who will win Chile’s 2017 presidential election?
preds:
Polls are banned in the weeks ahead of the election but analysts say that based on the last polls released and trends seen, it appears the race is now up for grabs. “What it is showing, though, is that there’s practically a tie between the two of them,” said Javier Sajuria, a lecturer in politics at Queen Mary University of London.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/uncertainty-reigns-in-tight-chilean-presidential-election/2017/12/15/90ae4a7e-e1fa-11e7-b2e9-8c636f076c76_story.html

Looked at Polling data listed by Cadem on Wikipedia. Piñera consistently ahead but just barely. With the margin of error it is a toss up. However, there is some expectation that young voters are not inspired by either candidate and will sit out the election. This favors Piñera.

The wind seems to be blowing in favor of the Chilean right. The country’s left-wing parties are fragmented. Its current socialist government, headed by Michelle Bachelet, is deeply unpopular. And a few days before the runoff election on Sunday to choose the country’s next leader, the center-right candidate, Sebastián Piñera, who won the first round of voting, on November 19, is polling three to five points ahead of his opponent, the independent senator Alejandro Guillier.

Base rate: Winning runoff elections in Latin America Chile is one of the Latin American countries with the most experience in runoff balloting. Of the seven presidential elections from 1989 to date, the last five required a second round. And on four of those five occasions, the second-round results confirmed the candidate who had won on the first round. 
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2017/12/12/winning-runoff-elections-in-latin-america/ BUT The first round of the Chilean presidential elections on November 19 produced a very surprising result. Against most expectations, conservative favourite Sebastián Piñera did not achieve a sweeping victory, receiving just 37 per cent of the vote, with his main opponent Alejandro Guillier from the left gaining a respectable 23 per cent. Yet the most notable result was the unheralded rise of the second leftist candidate Beatriz Sánchez, of the Broad Front.  Tearing up the predictions of Chilean pollsters, she took just 3 per cent less than Guillier, receiving a share of 20 per cent. Beatriz Sánchez and Marco Enríquez-Ominami, both eliminated in the first round (Patricio Alarcón, CC BY-NC-ND 2.0) The other two candidates, Carolina Goic of the Christian-Democrats and “the Chilean Trump” Jose-Antonio Kast, received 6 and 8 per cent, respectively.
http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/latamcaribbean/2017/12/12/chiles-2017-presidential-election-the-alliances-and-aspirations-of-pinera-and-guillier/ Goic + Guillier + Sánchez = 50%
Piñera + Kast             = 45% Given these numbers, a surprise alternative candidate stands no chance whatsoever. Especially since these are the only 2 alternatives on the ballot.

The Broad Front has not formally endorsed any candidate in the second round, but former candidate Beatriz Sanchez announced that her “vote is against Sebastian Piñera,” and therefore “for Alejandro Guillier.” The Christian Democratic Party, who had originally fielded their own candidate, has also backed Guillier. This makes me a little more confident that Guillier has a chance to unite the left which he will need to do if he's to win.
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Who-Will-Be-Chiles-Next-President-20171212-0026.html
BAcked by Financial institutions in Chile....people willing to give him a second chance
Name recognition and continuity go a long way in elections.

This may be a game changer. I will have to check the polls in next few days. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-politics/leftist-leader-backs-guillier-in-chiles-run-off-presidential-election-idUSKBN1DZ07P?il=0

If Guillier got more than 85% of the Sanchez' votes that were cast in round 1, he might be able to beat Piñera based on voter preferences  outlined in Criteria Research. Those preferences from Dec 1 opinion research indicated 77% of Sanchez votes may be cast for Guillier. This was before Sanchez indicated she personally would vote for Guillier. Jumping to 85% with all other assumptions staying the same, Piñera could beat Guillier by less than 1% with turnout expected to be lower than first round.
I'm not sure I believe 85% as endorsements from the left have been tepid. Staying with current forecast and tracking news for signs of momentum.

Not just the pollsters, Sanchez, GJ got it wrong, and massively too! The experts’ myopia is startling yet unsurprising. As Sánchez put it, finally letting loose against public-opinion shapers who consistently demeaned her and her party, “all these columnists who fill up pages in newspapers have no idea what happens, they have no clue about the real Chile.”
https://www.jacobinmag.com/2017/12/chile-elections-frente-amplio-concertation What a surprise!  Beatriz Sánchez, a journalist and the recently formed Frente Amplio coalition’s presidential candidate received over 20.27% of the popular vote in last months elections. Allejandro Guiller, the nominee from the incumbent President Michelle Machelet’s centre-left coalition Fuerza de la Mayoría (New Majority), just managed to reach the second round with 22.70%. With a slight lead over the Frente Amplio, he will now face former President Sebastián Piñera, of the centre-right coalition “Chile Vamos” (with 36.64%), in the runoff election. The result was a big shock for the centre-right, who were expecting a stronger first round. Not only was Piñera’s 10-point lead in the polls unfounded, but José Antonio Kast, a candidate from the far-right and known supporter of former dictator Pinochet, also enjoyed some electoral success (7.93%). Yet perhaps the biggest losers on 19th November were the pollsters who, as in many other popular votes around the world, are seeing their credibility vanish. The Frente Amplio is a great contrast to the fossilised leadership of the country’s traditional political coalitions. Yet it is the gains made by the Frente Amplio in both the parliamentary and the presidential elections that are of real significance. With their electoral successes (winning 20 deputies out of a possible 150), the coalition now holds the balance of power in the Parliament, together with the regionalist and independence parties. This means that their support will be necessary for the new president, elected from the second round on 17th December, to form a majority in parliament.
https://www.opendemocracy.net/democraciaabierta/CIVICUS/sebasti-n-vielmas/chiles-frente-amplio-brings-surprises No matter who wins the election, the left will hold power in Chile. Now that is a surprise result.

Well now that Sanchez has backed Guillier I have to adapt my forecast. Central to my forecast are three questions: 1. Does Sanchez's voters follow her lead and vote for Guillier? 
2. Will Guiller make concessions to Sanchez's party coalition?
3. How many voters will go to the ballot boxes in the end? While I believe that her public endorsement will have an influence on the vote, I'm still a bit sceptical if it leads Guillier to a win. That is mostly because of the overall voter turnout. In the first round voter turnout was 46,7%. In the last election in 2013 the turnout dropped from 49% in the first round to 42% in the second round. My assumption is that the endorsement may not only mobilize leftist voters for Guillier but also conservative voters for Pinera as well (well, that's an unsourced guess based on 'recent' elections in western countries, thus, may not be the case in Chile). As it's probable that some voters still do not decide to vote for Guiller (Sanchez's party coalition contains 14 different groups that made demands to Guiller for official support before but he didn't give in), Pinera may still win the vote. If Guiller should decide to comply with demands of Sanchez's party coalition I will have to change my estimate again. Until then it seems more probable that Pinera wins. Sources:
- http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/chile-s-leftists-stop-short-of-endorsing-presidential-candidate-guillier-9457472
- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-21/from-street-protests-to-kingmaker-chile-s-new-left-comes-of-age
- https://in.reuters.com/article/chile-politics/leftist-leader-backs-guillier-in-chiles-run-off-presidential-election-idINKBN1DZ07Z
- http://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/44/

VOA among others reports Sanchez and her Frente Amplio are backing Guillier. https://www.voanews.com/a/leftist-leader-backs-guillier-in-chile-run-off-presidential-election-/4149611.html   This crew could be more "motivated" to get folks to the polls to vote than the toffee-nose billionaire. opponent.  Oh, and here is a definition of a "toff" if you aren't sure what it means  https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/toffee-nosed

Beatriz Sanchez, the flagbearer for the hard-left Frente Amplio coalition, said Pinera’s suggestion that ballots had been tampered with in the first-round election had changed her mind about staying quiet on whom she would vote for in the run-off. “That crosses the line and that’s why today I’ve decided...to vote against Sebastian Pinera,” Sanchez told journalists. “My vote will be for Alejandro Guillier.” Winning over Sanchez voters has been seen as essential for a Guillier triumph over Pinera in the second-round vote. As Frente Amplio’s presidential candidate, Sanchez secured twice as many votes as expected by opinion polls and came two points short of moving onto the run-off election with Pinera. 
https://in.reuters.com/article/chile-politics/leftist-leader-backs-guillier-in-chiles-run-off-presidential-election-idINKBN1DZ07Z
Difficult to find current situation. Polling could be wrong. Guess it left will split and more Conservative Piñera wins.

With the rise of the new Chilean left the result is more uncertain than some may think. The central question is if Beatriz Sanchez and her movement of 13 (!) different groups will endorse Alejandro Guillier and provide the necessary votes to give him a realistic chance. It's probable that already some of her voters will vote for Gullier but that won't be enough to present a real challenge for Pinera. Some groups have already decided to back Gullier while some have denied support. At the moment, however, Pinera is most likely the next president of Chile. Sources:
- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-20/surprise-blow-to-billionaire-sends-chile-vote-to-a-second-round
- https://www.usnews.com/news/best-countries/articles/2017-11-29/chile-heads-into-a-presidential-runoff-with-a-transformed-political-landscape
- https://socialistproject.ca/bullet/1519.php

Chile election: Conservative Piñera to face Socialist Guillier in run-off
Mr Guillier won 22.7% of the vote. He is a former journalist and the candidate from Ms Bachelet's left-wing Nueva Mayoría coalition.
Let's see the second round on 17 December.
The candidate with momentum, Sanchez, has been eliminated, and the left vote is therefore divided. Pinera has been ahead in polling since the first round.
Albeit suspect methods of polling org indicate this now closer than many suspect  http://santiagotimes.cl/2017/11/27/cadem-publishes-first-post-election-study/ Guillier unlikely to be " Nasralla-ed"

Adjusting downward based on poll results here:
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Sebastian-Pinera-Leads-Vote-Intention-in-Chile--20171130-0023.html

The biggest political polling institute in Chile, Cadem has published its first post-election study, which measured the likely results of the second round of the presidential election happening on the 17th December. According to the results, Sebastián Piñera obtained 39.8% of mentions and Alejandro Guillier followed close behind with 37.3%. 22.9% responded as “don’t know”, “won’t vote”, or left the question blank.
http://santiagotimes.cl/2017/11/27/cadem-publishes-first-post-election-study/  If you apply a 5% correction to the polling results, because the polls overestimated Pinera by 5% in the 1st round, a clear win for Guillier emerges.

If you include just votes won by these two candidates its a 62-38% split. That moves up to ~75% if you include the votes almost guaranteed from Kast supporters. 
Guillier is likely to pick up some votes from the left himself which makes me nudge his chance up a bit. 
The largest polling institute in Chile has it pretty close but they were way off in the first round and have admitted they haven't had time to update their model so I'm not reading too much into that.
Reassessing. Note previous Bloomberg article but Guiller is gaining.
I think Piñera will win because Sánchez voters are split on whether to vote for Guiller. Guiller might not pick-up enough votes.

Data points that make me think this is more open than some seem to think it is:  - Latest poll (n=1442), 39.8% Pinera, 37.3% Guillier, 22,9% undecided/don't know: www.ahoranoticias.cl%2Fnoticias%2Fpolitica%2F210754-encuesta-cadem-la-segunda-vuelta-presidencial-se-encuentra-empatada.html%3AXjGppKquv-IuIjY7yFQxCydteZo&cuid=2886049
- Pinera going down in prediction markets: https://www.predictit.org/Contract/8331/Will-Sebasti%C3%A1n-Pi%C3%B1era-be-elected-president-of-Chile-in-2017#data and https://www.predictit.org/Market/3817/Who-will-be-elected-president-of-Chile-in-2017
- This analysis of the second round: http://santiagotimes.cl/2017/11/20/analysis-what-can-we-expect-from-the-second-round-of-the-elections-in-chile/ I'm inclined to go down to 60/40 even, but hesitant since many others seem to be quite confident in Pinera winning.

Best article I have found. Guillier could pull it off but it would be a long shot. Sticking with prediction. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-21/from-street-protests-to-kingmaker-chile-s-new-left-comes-of-age
Right wing candidates combined got 50.45% of votes in the general, which I expect will be a good predictor of the runoff.
Thanks to @JMR2017. good comment and analysis

It is interesting that Pinera did much worse than i expected, and Sanchez was very close to Guillier  in the first round. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chilean_general_election,_2017 I still expect Pinera to win on 17. Dec 
but the race in terms of % I suppose will be much closer.

Based on analysis of polling of first round election, Beatriz Sanchez beat all expectations. Overall turnout in the second round is expected to be less (42%) than the first round (46.6%). This also happened in 2013, the first election where voting became voluntary. Polling analysis offers predictions on the transfer of votes from candidates who lost from round one to round 2: Round 2 predictions based on following calculations: 
Approx. drop off of 1 million votes Piñera receives 86% of JAK votes and 15% of Goic votes = Estimated 2.92 million total votes - 51.3% Guillier receives 77% of Sanchez votes and 63% of Goic votes = Estimated 2.77 million total votes - 48.6% Sanchez has not endorsed Guillier and news reports indicate that she probably won't but stated that Piñera would clearly be worse.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-21/from-street-protests-to-kingmaker-chile-s-new-left-comes-of-age

Moderating my expectations some. Santiago Stock Exchange fell 5% on Pinera’s less than stellar performance, indicating some nervousness on the part of investors with real money at stake. (http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/world/chile-pinera-guillier-sanchez-1.4410669 , paragraph 3).  Still, I think he remains the favorite.

Dateline 11-20-2017 Chile's presidential election will go to a December run-off vote, after conservative Sebastian Pinera won the first round but fell short of an outright victory.  Pinera, a billionaire ranked by Forbes magazine as the third richest person in Chile, won 36.6 percent of Sunday's vote. Socialist Alejandro Guiller came second, with nearly 23 percent. -- http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/sebastian-pinera-face-alejandro-guiller-run-171120143711160.html

Piñera 36.6% 
Guillier’s 22.7% 
Very low turnout, 46.6%
http://santiagotimes.cl/2017/11/20/chile-elections-2017-pinera-wins-first-round-of-chile-election-faces-runoff/     A possible left-wing alliance of Guillier (22,8%) + ME-O (5,7%) + Sánchez (20,3%) = 48,8%
    A possible right-wing alliance of Piñera (36,6%) + Kast (7,9%) = 44,5% As can be seen, the disappointing result for Goic could make her play a remarkable role in the second round. Assuming that people who voted in the first round will vote in the second round. Whether it´s Alejandro Guillier or Sebastián Piñera who governs Chile from 2018 until 2022, their main concern should be reinstating confidence of the public in the political system of Chile. The rise of the more revolutionary Frente Amplio and the ultra-right-wing independent candidate José Antonio Kast in combination with the low turnout (46%) make one thing clear: Chileans are far from satisfied with their country at the moment.
http://santiagotimes.cl/2017/11/20/analysis-what-can-we-expect-from-the-second-round-of-the-elections-in-chile/
More confident after looking at others predictions.
Polls indicate it comes down to these two. Could be wrong.

Piñera appears to have outperformed the final CEP poll. http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-chile-election-20171119-story.html https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-politics-poll/pinera-holds-lead-in-chiles-presidential-race-poll-idUSKBN1CU2BS

Pineda has 36.67% in the 1st round  with 81.75% of the vote counted.   Expectation was 42%.
https://www.voanews.com/a/chile-presidential-election/4126119.html
Short term flyer on outcome of first round.
A Chile Trumpet with a Spainish accent?! Ai caramba! Sebastian Trumpinera

1.A low voter turnout is expected for Chile's upcoming General Election, playing in the hands of the conservatives
https://videosenglish.telesurtv.net/video/688493/chiles-general-elections-and-the-problem-with-low-turnout/ 2. Left parties are divided, instead of united behind a single candidate. Chile's Trump is now almost guaranteed a win. Pinochet 2.0.

1.With their six rivals trailing far behind, Pinera and Guillier are widely expected to place first and second, respectively, in Sunday’s election, allowing them to move on to an eventual Dec. 17 run-off. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-election-closing-campaigns/chiles-presidential-hopefuls-wrap-up-campaigning-ahead-of-sunday-vote-idUSKBN1DG350?il=0 This means all other candidates have a zero percent chance of winning. The probability of Pinera securing at least 50 percent of votes needed to avoid a runoff election was only slightly better at 0.001 percent, it added in an email. Still, riding high with more than double Guillier’s support in recent polls, Pinera urged Chileans to “make it short” and vote for him on Sunday to give him an outright win.  2. Sebastian doesn't have large enough lead to win outright, forcing him into a runoff. This means Guillier could topple him.
Guillier will need a large turnout to have any chance (50%+) at all and runoffs usually see a significant drop in voter turnout.
Bachelet's government is perceived as ineffective, enhancing the center-right chances.
Pinera seems to be holding onto his solid but not insurmountable lead.

Chileans seem to be relatively disillusioned, believing that the path they are on will remain constant regardless of who sits in the presidential chair. Sebastian Pinera has, a few things working towards his favor. He has a proven track record (both positives and negatives), he's a wealthy business man who proposes to cut government spending and improve the economy. In interviews, Pinera also seems to carry himself with more digestible and "likeable" aura of self confidence that copmliments his character and political strengths. However, Alejandro Guillier is likely to come in 2nd and it is too soon to predict where the country will lean in the December run off election.
Pinera's party will get out the vote which will be determining factor since voting is no longer mandatory.

Estimated First Round to November 03: Sebastián Piñera 45%, Alejandro Guillier 23%, Beatriz Sánchez 14%, Carolina Goic 6%, José Antonio Kast 6%, Marco Enríquez Ominami 5%, Alejandro Navarro 0.5% and Eduardo Artés 0.5%. https://plazapublica.cl/temas/encuestas/#post-15417

Why do people think/ believe/ hope across the democracies of this globe, that billionaires will do the best fro them and the country?  Why do young people leave it to the departing generation to shape their (the young ones') future and do not participate in the elections?  Functioning democracies only become better through constant frictions and resolving them. There is no such a thing that one alone has the one and only formula. Politics and Business are two pair of shoes, if they function both optimal, they complement to each other and pave the way for success of the society. The USP's for both are however different and the people fitting in these shoes are different too.  I am specifically curious about the outcome of this type of forecasting where populistic arguments cannot be put into hard facts numbers (forecasts). I am specifically interested about; who wins the race of human forecasting against AI in the "HFC" competition.

I am rethinking all the predictions and the forecasts in the wake of the rebirth of populism?  
The mood of the voters is short sighted and very shaky, rumors and manipulations can result in big and unexpected changes. I specifically think of the vulnerability of an election system as is in place in Chile. from the first to the second electoral round, there is no such thing as a  "sure" winner.
for the second round everything is open again, it is a question of mobilization. Still, I remain with my forecasted numbers for now and will observe carefully. http://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/23/populism-is-coming-for-latin-america-in-2018/

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-politics/low-turnout-in-chile-election-could-hand-victory-to-pinera-idUSKBN1D62CV?il=0 SANTIAGO (Reuters) - The frontrunner for Chile’s presidency, billionaire businessman Sebastian Pinera, faces an array of left-wing parties in this year’s elections but he can expect help from one quarter - low turnout.

Recent opinion polls give Pinera, a conservative former president, a commanding lead over his seven mostly left-of-center rivals for the Nov. 19 first round but predict he is unlikely to take the more than 50 percent needed to avoid a run-off.
Current polls show Pinera with the lead however nearly 1/3 of voters are undecided

So the beauty of this question is that it's really a question of:  "Will there be a run-off?" If there is no run-off Pinera wins 100% of the time.  However, he needs to get 50% of the votes for that to happen. My model has that happening just over 10% of the time.  After which, in a run-off I have him winning roughly 60% of the time and the opponent 40%.   I have heavily weighted the Pinera outright wins in my forecast with the intent on changing it if a run-off is involved.

Thank you to @JMR2017, @Poli_Sci_Guy, @Raahul_Kumar and @mwokasch , for the great comments and links. 
It is really difficult to keep an overview of the progressing growth of political parties. Also the growing populism around the world and Chile seems no different makes predictions about the outcome of elections anywhere ever more difficult !
Recent poll has Pinera at 32.8, Guillermo at 14.3 and Sanchez about 7%. Polls can be wrong.
Tack to the right after Bachelet fatigue
Pinera will win first round, but not enough to prevent a 2nd round. In 2nd round election will be much more competitive, Guillier will challenge decently.
Recent polls indicate that Pinera maintains his lead in voter preference while Sanchez has slipped.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Chile elections: why progressives will not win 
https://www.opendemocracy.net/democraciaabierta/claudio-fuentes-saavedra/chile-elections-why-progressives-will-not-win The left is fragmented into 6 different parties. No chance of victory exists.
Boots on the ground say it's going to be Piñera.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Pinera has consistently led in the polls.

Sebastián Piñera: 45%
Alejandro Guillier: 21%
Beatriz Sánchez: 12% 
Undecided: 11% It's starting to look like Pinera can't be beaten if these numbers still look like this on election day.

Lower voter turnout and high levels of disinterest in politics including among young people in Chile may give the candidate to the right (Piñera) a slight advantage.  Elections are all about turnout. Chilean election turnout changed drastically in 2012 when voting became voluntary and voter registration became automatic.  The 2017 Presidential primary showed the lowest turnout in history (Wikipedia) at 13% of the voting age population compared to 23% for the same first round election in 2013. However, in the 12-15-13 Presidential runoff, turnout was 41.98%. This compares to 86.94% turnout in the 2010 Presidential runoff. Trends (while just new and recent since the last Presidential election was 2013) indicate that with lower turnout, there is greater inequality in terms of rich and poor with rich people turning out in greater numbers.  http://themonkeycage.org/2013/07/turnout-rates-among-the-rich-and-poor/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2013/11/10/buyers-remorse-in-chilean-elections/ https://www.oecd.org/els/family/CO_4_2_Participation_first_time_voters.pdf Other rule changes affect how districts are set up but while this has less to do with the direct vote for President may indicate voter motivation to turn out. http://www.latinamericamonitor.com/political-risk-analysis-chile-vamos-likely-win-general-elections-while-independents-make-historic
Excerpts:
"This populist anger - alongside infighting within the NM - has caused the number of official parties to grow from 15 to 32, with the majority of the new parties on the left. We expect these parties to gain seats in congress in the general elections, benefitting from Chile's new electoral rules. This will further fracture the left-wing of Chilean politics, preventing a unified opposition to the CV. Moreover, we note that the greatest challenge to Piñera's candidacy will come not from the political mainstream but rather from independent leftist candidate Alejandro Guillier, who received 20.0% support in recent polling, in addition to the highest confidence ratings of any candidate. While not our core scenario, we cannot rule out the possibility that Guillier defeats Piñera, particularly if persistent gridlock further amplifies public anger towards the political establishment ( see 'Ascendant Left Wing Will Weigh On Reforms', August 23). While it is difficult to project what a Guillier administration would look like at this stage, it is likely that it would pursue increases in public spending and pro-labour reforms, to the detriment of the stable, business-friendly reputation Chile has cultivated in recent decades. That said, we note that a Guillier administration would face strong resistance from the right and centre-left elements of Chile's Congress, limiting the administration's ability to pass legislation." Business interests, clearly motivated in this election face populist anger however split and diluted among a greater number of parties. A good economy combined with relatively high levels of disinterest in politics should give Piñera the edge in a runoff.

Despite his conservative agenda  on social issues the rapid economic growth and a steep drop in unemployment during his term from 2010 to 2014, make Sebastian Pinera quite popular. Currently is ahead in the polls. 
Beatriz Sanchez has a progressive agenda and her candidacy grows progressively. 
Alejandro Guillier is quite popular but his political message is not clear.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

I hate elections questions, but what the heck. I know my intuition on elections is terrible, so I'll follow @shivadiva's explanation and evaluation of probabilities at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/592165 plus his/her final adjustment that same day. I have more faith in the judgment of another forecaster when the forecaster makes several adjustments soon after considering the data.
Guillier suggests more change from the recent state of things due to not beeing the current leader.
I want to give Sanchez the edge, but press and markets and polls are very pro-pinera

Primaries will likely see Pinera vs Sanchez.  Sanchez likely to win due to:
- conservatives seem to be in process of re-marketing themselves: so past iteration wasn't for them with electorate. Voters tend to make decisions on who to vote in next election based on how they feel the last term went with the centrists (not well) and pro-business platform of conservatives might be appealing +20% -New version of Conservatives still include pro-Pinochet and right-wing members from before so how will voters think the current coalition is any different from the last? My guess is current leaders are arrogant enough to think they can still sell this with themselves at the helm, rather than endorse a new guy. -20% - population seems to dislike corruption issues based on literary themes, past history and seem to favor egalitarian distribution policies. Conservative coalition has history of graft, corruption, bribery charges, etc. (probably the other side does too but it's the conservative egress in the news right now). -10% -Current areas of popular discontent seem to be around education and retirement - caring for young and old (liberal platform) and not around economic growth/trade (conservative). -20% - Pinera, and Ossandon seem to be, how to say, a bit behind the times when it comes to equality of gender, sexual orientation, and economic-socio disparities? This is at the country of Isabel Allende but strong male image works in many elections  +10% - public ongoing protests - for everyone that risks physical harm by protesting out in the open, there are likely scores more who are dissatisfied but stay home who will exercise their opinion with their vote. -20% -Pinera  said he will completely separate his role as president and abandon "any legitimate interest of a private nature," This was also a point of controversy during his first presidency. I believe he plans to do this the way donald trump has with his empire: legally sign paperwork saying he's not the head but he knows in practice with a wide-ranging empire, it is impossible to not be involved to a great but indirect degree. Not sure if Colombians will believe this promise - they might not. -20 % But being a billionaire carries weight, perceived as a successful person +10
- support of international markets +10
- country seems three generations removed from Pinochet era and global business friendly. Markets seem to support Pinera +20% - People don’t seem to believe Felipe Kast is “modern and genuinely liberal” or, perhaps more they don’t believe (because he only has three percent support in his coalition), he is nothing like his pro-Pinochet ministerial father. Sanchez has 74% coalition support "according to polls” compared to the second place, Mayol (11%) so I’d say it is really hers to lose and not Pinera’s. This is significant to me ito the polarization of support towards her (not that Hilary wasn’t a lesson for all of us but…) I do think this will place her as the Liberal contender +20 Sanchez seems authentic ito of social agenda:

I think these are exactly the sorts of issues the Chilean people are having trouble with from their previous elected leaders. +20 https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Whos-Who-in-Primary-Elections-For-Chiles-New-President-20170629-0017.html, https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-election-markets/chile-left-wing-candidates-could-form-alliance-threatening-market-rally-idUSKCN1C131G and wiki pages
Not convinced the far left would compromise in order to support a center left candidate in the runoff.

Voters in Chile are ready for a change in the party running the country.  Mr. Pinera has the backing of the business establishment and a vast personal fortune.  It is hard to imagine his advantages not being enough to win.  Only an upset of the Trump type would open the door for Guillier. He is an anti establishment candidate and if a "vote for change" or "drain the swamp" took hold among the electorate it is possible he could do the upset.  Certainly his politics are not that of Trump but his message sounds familiar to what won for Trump.
Too stable to shake things up.

Sebastian Pinera has been able to increase support from 40% to 43% over the past months and Alejandro Guillier is quite far behind (but still the closest) with 20%. 
Despite Pinera in the lead, there is a story here in Chile that the electorate is not totally convinced which direction the country should take. Pinera would certainly be a very business oriented persident who runs the country more like a firm.

Most recent poll (http://www.euronews.com/2017/10/03/chiles-pinera-would-win-44-pct-in-presidential-first-round-pollster) suggestst that Guillier and Pinera enter the second round and Sanchez is likely to be eliminated for the run-off. This might need adjustment when more information becomes available.
PIggybacking on other forecasters, waiting for more info.

Latest poll has Pinera at 44%, Guillier at 30%, Sanchez at 11%. Pinera is conservative, Gullier is center-left. Sanchez and the other candidates in the election are on the left wing of the political spectrum. Most of their voters will probably vote for Guillier in a run-off. Pinera has an advantage, but it's not decisive. https://www.voanews.com/a/pinera-maintains-lead-chilean-presidential-election/4054823.html

Sanchez is certain to be eliminated. That will mean his voters will consolidate with Guillier, who may beat Pinera in a repeat of the upset election in Peru. Fuji was the GJ favourite. http://edition.cnn.com/2016/06/10/americas/peru-president/

C.R. polls indicate 2nd round could be close.
Cadem polls list Pinera with 10% leads against both Guillier and Sanchez in the 2nd round.
Any upset will depend on effective consolidation of the opposition to Pinera.

Pinera current has a comfortable lead in the polls, around twice that of his serious opponents. But he's not at fifty so there will most likely be a runoff and in that case I think Guillier rather than Sanchez is more likely to win as he is the more moderate centrist candidate.
